column9: TEXT
(technical difficulty)
This quarter and first half financial results briefing.
This morning, we announced a record net profit of $2.35 billion for the first half, up 4% from the year ago and total income was also at a new high.
For the second quarter, net profit rose 8%.
The board also declared a higher dividend for the first half.
And to tell us more today, we have with us our CEO Piyush Gupta; and our CFO Sok Hui Lim.
So without further ado, Sok Hui Lim.
Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter results briefing.
We achieved record earnings of $2.35 billion for the first half, up 4% from year ago.
Total income reached a half year high of $5.81 billion as broad based loan growth and record fee income offset the impact of lower net interest margins and weaker trading performance.
Expenses were 1% lower at $2.52 billion as digitization and productivity initiatives resulted in a 1 percentage point improvement in the cost-income ratio to 43%.
Total allowances declined 6% to $504 million as NPA formation was lower.
For the second quarter, net profit rose 8% from a year ago to $1.14 billion.
Total income of $2.92 billion was just shy of a quarterly high.
Business momentum was healthy as loans grew a 2% over the quarter and the fee income trends were sustained.
Total allowances fell 17% to $304 million from a high year ago base.
The balance sheet continues to be sound.
New NPA formation in the first and second quarters were lower than the levels in the preceding 3 quarters.
The amount of nonperforming assets was little changed from the previous quarter as nonperforming loan formation was offset by write-offs and recoveries.
Allowance coverage was at 100% and 234% when collateral was considered.
Our capital and liquidity ratios remained well above regulatory requirements with the final Common Equity Tier 1 ratio at 14.0% and the liquidity coverage ratio at 150%.
The board declared a 10% increase in dividends to $0.33 per share.

The increase is consistent with our policy of paying progressive dividends in line with earnings while maintaining prudent capital levels to meet impending regulatory changes and long-term growth requirements.
For the first half, net profit of $2.35 billion rose 4% or $96 million from a year ago.
Net interest income rose 1% or $53 million to $3.72 billion.
Loans increased 6% or $18 billion to $303 billion from broad-based growth in trade, corporate, consumer and Singapore housing loans.
The increase in loan volumes was offset by a 12 basis points decline in net interest margin to 1.74% due to softer Singapore dollar interest rates.
Net fee income rose 8% or $99 million to $1.30 billion with the increase coming almost entirely from Wealth management fees.
Fees from card and transaction services were also higher.
The increases were partially offset by low investment fees as we had several large equity underwriting transactions in 2016.
Other noninterest income fell 14% or $126 million to $719 million from lower trading gains and a non-recurring gain of $38 million a year ago.
Expenses declined 1% or $34 million to $2.52 billion from ongoing digitalization and productivity initiatives.
Profits before allowances increased 2% to $3.29 billion.
Total allowances of $504 million was 6% lower than a year ago.
Specific allowances declined $216 million in line with lower NPA formation, partially offset by the impact of a $228 million general allowance write back in the second quarter last year.
For the second quarter, net profit of $1.14 billion was 8% or $89 million higher than a year ago.
Total income of $2.92 billion was a near quarterly high.
There was little change year-on-year as higher net interest income offset the impact of lower trading, investment and fixed asset again.

Net interest income rose 3% or $55 million to $1.89 billion as the impact of the 6% of loan growth was partially offset by lower net interest margin, which declined 13 basis points to 1.74% due to softer Singapore dollar interest rate.
Net fee income increased 1% or $8 million to $636 million.
The strong increase in annual fee income streams led by Wealth Management was offset by halving of investment banking fees from second quarter '16, a bumper quarter of new equity listings.
Other noninterest income fell 13% or $58 million, to $400 million as trading income and gains from investment securities were lower.
There have also been gains from fixed assets a year ago.
Expenses fell 1% or $17 million to $1.27 billion.
The reduction in expenses contributed to a 1% increase in profits before allowances to $1.66 billion.
Specific allowances of $304 million were almost half of the amount a year ago.
The reduction was partially offset by the impact of the general allowance write back last year.
Compared to the previous quarter, net profit of $1.14 billion was 6% lower.
Total income rose 1% or $38 million to $2.92 billion, which was a near quarterly high.
Net interest income of $1.89 billion was 3% or $57 million higher as loans grew 2% from higher corporate, trade and consumer loans.
Net interest margin was unchanged at 1.74% as the benefit of higher Singapore dollar interest rates was offset by lower Hong Kong dollar rates.
Fee income of $636 million was 4% or $29 million below the record in the previous quarter.
Loan related and investment banking fees were lower.
Other fee income streams such as Wealth Management and transaction service fees were healthy and around the recent quarterly highs.
Other noninterest income of $400 million was 3% or $10 million higher.
An improvement in trading income partially offset lower gains from investment securities.
Expenses of $1.27 billion was 2% or $20 million higher.
Profit before allowances of $1.66 billion was 1% higher.
Specific allowances of $304 million were $104 million higher bringing first half allowances to $504 million.
Second quarter net interest income of $1.89 billion was 3% higher than both the previous quarter and a year ago.
For the first half, net interest income was 1% higher at $3.72 billion.
Second quarter net interest margin was unchanged from the previous quarter at 1.74%.
The impact of higher Singapore dollar interest rates was offset by a decline in Hong Kong dollar interbank rates.
We expect net interest margin to be slightly higher in the second half of the year as we are seeing more of a pass through of higher U.S. LIBOR rates on SIBOR and SOR.
In constant currency terms, overall gross loans rose $7 billion or 2% from the previous quarter and $16 billion or 5% from a year ago to $307 billion.
The growth was broad based.
Consumer loans rose $2 billion or 2% during the quarter and $4 billion or 5% from a year ago.
Wealth Management loans and Singapore housing loans contributed to the increase in both periods.
Corporate loans grew $4 billion or 2% during the quarter and $7 billion or 4% from a year ago.
The increase during the quarter was led by acquisition and real estate financing by Singapore and Hong Kong corporates.
Trade loans grew $3 billion or 7% during the quarter and $5 billion or 13% from a year ago to $43 billion.
The increase during the quarter reflect the stronger import and exports data in recent months.
Our loan pipeline remains healthy and we expect second half loan growth to be at similar levels to first half.
On top of that, the ANZ integration will add another $8 billion to $9 billion in second half of 2017.
Deposits rose 1% the previous quarter and 9% from a year ago in constant currency terms to $343 billion.
About 60% of the growth from a year ago was in current and savings accounts reflecting the success of our Cash Management and consumer businesses in growing a stable lower cost deposits.
Other funding rose $2 billion during the quarter to $34 billion from issuances of commercial papers.
Our liquidity ratios remained well above regulatory requirements.
The liquidity coverage ratio was at 150% but the net stable funding ratio exceeded the requirements of 100% due in 2018.
Second quarter gross fee income of $731 million was 4% higher than a year ago and 1% below the record in the previous quarter.
Investment banking and loan related fees were lower compared to both periods muting the healthy performance in other fee income streams.
The $245 million in Wealth Management fees during the quarter included $23 million of service fees from in-house treasury products now sold on open architecture platforms.
Compared to a year ago, the underlying increase was 24% reflecting franchise growth and more buoyant market conditions.
Card fees of $130 million were higher than a year ago as Singapore and Hong Kong credit card transactions grew.
Transaction service fees grow 4% from a year ago to $154 million from increased Cash Management fees.
Offsetting the growth of these fee activities was the halving the investment banking fees from a year ago, when we had a bumper quarter due to
(technical difficulty)
quarter to $104 million as lower fees were recognized from loan syndication and other loan related activities.
For the first half, gross fee income was 10% higher at $1.47 billion as Wealth Management, card and transaction service fees grew.
First-half pretax profit from Institutional Banking rose 23% from a year ago to $1.28 billion as allowances declined.
Total income was 1% lower at $2.62 billion.
Cash Management income grew 28% to $506 million, reflecting steady growth in customers and mandates.
The increase was offset by lower contributions from loan, treasury, customer as well as investment banking activities.
Expenses rose 1% to $860 million while profits before allowances declined 3% to $1.76 billion.
Allowances fell by -- to $480 million in line with lower NPL formation in the oil and gas support services sector.
Asset balances rose 7% or $15 billion to $236 billion, as both trade and nontrade loans grew.
Cash Management deposits were 7% higher at $130 billion.
First-half pretax profit for consumer banking and Wealth Management rose 12% to a new high of $1.0 billion.
Total income grew 10% or $207 million to a record $2.30 billion.
Investment product income rose 21% to $684 million from broad-based growth across unit trusts and treasury products.
Loan and deposit income grew 6% to $1.29 billion from higher housing loan and deposit volumes, partially offset by a lower net interest margin.
Cards income grew 6% to $293 million in line with increased customer transactions.
Wealth Management customer segment rose 27% to $1.03 billion as assets under management grew 16% to $175 billion.
The amount does not include ANZ, which will increase our AUM further when it is integrated from second half 2017.
Income from retail customer segment declined 1% to $1.27 billion as volume growth was offset by lower net interest margin.
Our market share in Singapore housing loans increased from a year ago, while we continue to add more than 50% of Singapore dollar savings deposit market share.
Expenses rose 8% to $1.23 billion from increased investments and marketing activities.
The cost income ratio declined 1 percentage points for consumer banking to 54%.
Total allowances rose $11 million to $66 million with the increase due to general allowances taken in line with loan growth.

First-half treasury customer income fell 5% to $594 million as an increase in income from Wealth Management customers was more than offset by a decline from corporate customers mainly due to lower R&D hedging activities.
Income from the Treasury Markets business segment, which reflects structuring, market-making and trading activities, fell 23% to $445 million.
The weaker results were due to less favorable performance in interest-rate activities.
Total treasury income amounted to $1.04 billion, 14% below a year ago.
First-half expenses fell 1% to $2.52 billion.
For the second quarter, expenses were also 1% lower than a year ago at $1.27 billion.
The decline marked the fourth consecutive quarter of year-on-year declines reflecting sustained improvement in operating efficiency from digitalization and productivity initiatives.
Similarly, underlying headcount has been falling gradually over the past few quarters and is more than 2% lower than at the start of 2016.
The cost to income ratio improved from 44% a year ago to 43%.
We expect the ratio to be around 43% for full year 2017.
Hong Kong first half net profit rose 24% from a year ago to $457 million.
Total income grew 4% to $1.06 billion.
Net interest income was 7% or $44 million higher at $694 million.
The impact of higher asset volumes and an improved deposit mix was partially offset by 6 basis point declines in net interest margin to 1.74% due to lower HIBOR rate.
Fee income rose 29% or $64 million to $283 million from broad-based growth led by Wealth Management, Cash Management and investment banking.
Other noninterest income declined 46% or $72 million from lower trading gains and treasury customer flows.
There was also an absence of gains from fixed assets from a year ago.
Expenses were stable at $465 million.
The positive jaw resulted in a 5% increase in profits before allowances to $595 million.
Total allowances declined $79 million to $46 million from lower specific allowances.
General allowances rose $27 million in line with loan growth.
Nonperforming assets.
Nonperforming assets of $4.85 billion were little changed from the previous quarter as nonperforming loan formation was offset by write offs and recoveries.
The nonperforming loan ratio rose slightly to 1.5%.
NPA formation during the quarter continued to include several oil and gas support services exposure.
There were also 2 secured exposures to India including one that was still current.
The writeoff  included partial write-downs of 2 oil and gas support service exposures provided for previously.
Specific allowance charges for the quarter amounted to $304 million.
Our allowance coverage of nonperforming assets was at 100% taking into account collateral, which is valued at $2.79 billion, coverage of unsecured nonperforming assets was at 234%.
Our capital ratio remains strong.

The fully phased-in Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was 14.0%, slightly lower than the 14.2% in the previous quarter, as an increase in retained earnings was offset by dividends paid and an increase in risk weighted assets.
Our leverage ratio was stable at 7.9%, more than twice the minimum of 3% [mandated] by the Basel committee.
Dividends.
The interim Dividend of $0.33 per share represents a $0.03 or 10% increase from recent payouts.
Based on yesterday's closing price, the annualized dividend yield is 3.0%.

The payout, which amounts to 36% of our first half earnings is consistent with our policy of paying sustainable dividends over time consistent with our capital management objective, long-term growth prospects and the need to maintain prudent capital levels in view of the uncertain impact of regulatory change.
The Scrip dividend scheme will apply to this dividend.
Shareholders electing to dividend in scrip will be issued new shares at the average of the closing share prices on 11th, 14th and 15th of August.
In summary, we delivered a strong operating performance in the first half.
Loan growth was broad-based and fee income rose to a record.
The results were muted by lower Singapore dollar interest rates and the weaker trading performance.
Our business pipeline is healthy.
The business momentum in the second quarter has continued into July.
We expect a broad-based loan growth across trade, corporate and Singapore housing loans to continue.
Net interest margin is likely to improve slightly in the second half.
The extent of the increase will depend on the flow through of the U.S. dollar LIBOR and Singapore dollar SOR and SIBOR rate.
Fee income growth will continue to be supported by multiple activities including Wealth Management and Cash Management.
The asset quality will remain under pressure and we expect heightened credit costs in the oil and gas support services sector to persist with the low oil prices.
The 10% dividend increase reflects the board's confidence in the quality of our earnings and balance sheet especially the strong capital buffers we have built.
Thank you, and I'll now hand you over to Piyush.
So I guess, as Sok Hui pointed out if we go back.
The second quarter, I think one of the key things to look at is that I'd call it a noisy quarter from an income standpoint.
And a few things to draw your attention to.
One, loan growth was about $6 billion, but it was substantially back ended.

So most of the loan growth actually came in June, which means, if we look at our average asset growth for the quarter, it's actually only about $1 billion and change, even though loan --  the quarter-on-quarter growth was about $6 billion.
The good news is, as Sok Hui said, the momentum has continued so we are starting see very strong loan growth into the third quarter as well and end of July.
The second noise is really from NIM.
Now NIM has 2 impacts.
One is obviously the impact from SIBOR and SOR.
And second quarter, saw the impact of LIBOR and seasonal SIBOR and SOR were somewhat muted.
So the amount of pass-through that we have seen in the quarter was in the region of about 35% odd percent of LIBOR.
We pointed out earlier that historically this should be 60% to 70%, so obviously, it's been somewhat subdued although it was positive.
The problem was really Hong Kong, where HIBOR, particularly 1 month HIBOR, which is what we price our loans off, that took a massive dip.
And that took a massive dip just because of the tremendous amount of Hong Kong dollar liquidity in the system.
And as we pointed out the last time, our deposit franchise in Hong Kong has now become heavily geared to risk because of our CASA mix.
Our CASA mix there is also about 60% and therefore when HIBOR comes off, that puts a squeeze on our net interest margin.
So we basically picked up about 2 basis points in Singapore and we gave up 2 basis points in Hong Kong, and which is why we wound up with a flat NIM for the quarter.
Again, I can talk about it (inaudible).
July saw SIBOR, HIBOR, everything's picking up and everything's opened up.
And I think, based on our assessment of currency projections, I think there's upside in the rates in the second half.
I'll talk about that in a bit.
On fee income, as Sok Hui pointed out again, our actual fee income on the annuity fee businesses, whereas cards, transaction banking was very solid.
But on a year-on-year, we saw pro forma comparison with investment banking and actually more specifically with Equity Capital Markets.
Debt Capital Markets were up year-on-year.
But you see in last year's second quarter, we did a couple of big deals like the Manulife deal.

And as a consequence, while we had a good investment banking quarter, it just pales in comparison to the quarter we had last year, we are off by $40 million, $50 million on fee income just because of comparison effects.
And finally, markets.
The good news is the second quarter was much better than the first quarter.
First quarter, the trading was very challenged.
Second quarter was much stronger.
But again, year-on-year, the second quarter is still poorer than second quarter last year.
And therefore, the overall challenge that I see in the markets for this year relative to last year, continues to be there.
It's still not -- and most of it on the rates front.
FX and et cetera is OK, the rates front continues to be somewhat challenged in to -- comparing last year to this year.

So I guess, the key thing is it's been a noisy quarter for a lot of reasons but, slide -- I put in the slides just to emphasize that if we think about the underlying business momentum for our key businesses, it has been very strong.
So on mortgage, we pointed out before that we continue to grow mortgage market share in Singapore.
Between last year and this year, our market share is up by almost another percent, 18 basis points.
And better news is that our new bookings for the second quarter were the highest in 5 years.
So there has been a very clear pickup in housing activity in Singapore in the second quarter of this year, that's coming not just from new launches but also resale and refinancing.
Because the booking was so high, we expect the flow through of that to show up in the second and the third and fourth quarters of this year.
It's looking quite healthy and promising.
[Significantly on] cards our market shares on both billings and on receivables continues to increase.
In fact, in the last year, again in both categories, the ending net receivables as well as billings, we're up almost 1 percentage points of market share in both.
And these market shares are a record for us.
We previously have never had such high market shares on the cards business.
So again, momentum is a very good in terms of the business and that we've been able to get on cards.
On Wealth Management, we had 16% growth in AUMs over the year, roughly $175 billion for all Wealth AUMs.
And when we add on ANZ, which will happen now over the next 3 quarters, that should be worth another $20-odd billion on top of the $175 billion.
So again momentum continues to be very good, solid business growth.
And finally we take transaction banking, cash management and security services, we are up 28% year-on-year increments.
So that's again, very solid.
We're getting all the usual growth.
We're winning regional deals, we're winning multinational deals.
Our balances are going up so it continues to be very solid.
And on trade, as you know, our trade book [was small] between 2014, 2015.
But in the last year, the book has been consistently building.
And at the end of June, our total trade book, both the loans and as well as the bank was up to $47 billion again.
So you can see all the key underlying parts of our business on the consumer side and as well as in the corporate side, are exhibiting very strong momentum.
Slide.
ANZ, a quick word we're making good progress so we completed the China integration, it went smoothly.
It's a small business so it doesn't move the needle very much and is relatively uncomplicated.
We scheduled to do Singapore tomorrow and the day after, over this weekend.
It should be -- it's a fairly large business, 300,000 customers.
I'm hoping it will be smooth.
There is some hours of inconvenience to some of our existing customers if they can't use their debit cards for 2 or 3 hours tomorrow.
They can use the next card but they can't use the debit card.
But we've made adequate arrangements and advised customers in advance so hopefully will not be too much of a challenge.
We should be able to get Hong Kong done in the third quarter.
Taiwan in the fourth quarter and then Indonesia in the first quarter next year.
So we're on track.
We projected that once we get this done, we should get about a $600 million lift in top line next year from the ANZ integration and that's on track.
So we still hope to be able to get a $600 million lift in revenues next year on the back of the integration.
So far, we've made offers about 85 odd percent of all the employees we are targeting to join us have accepted.
So that's on track.
And as best I can tell, about 85%, 90% of all the original AUMs that went under consideration, we should be able to move.
So that's what is the basis of that $600 million number for next year.
So again, tracking fine.
Next on expenses.
Sok Hui pointed out expenses not only the cost and commissions have been improving.
Absolute expenses have been coming off.
In the first half of this year, absolute expenses are down 1% and that reflects all the effort we're making in multiple ways.
First, we are seeing real improvement in our channels and in our distribution costs.
So the ATM network, the cash deposit machines, the branch footprint, the contact center, we've been able to rationalize and take costs out of every one of these.
In the branches, we're putting watcher teller machines, we're putting video teller machines, we're -- in the contact center, we're using data analytics to reduce the call and call volume.
We're putting in cash recyclers so we don't -- we reduce the number of cash trips we make because people can recycle cash back into the same machine.
So again, there's a substantial cost reduction in the distribution.
We're seeing cost-reduction by digitizing the [inputting] process.
So our digital acquisitions can -- have been improved.
In the past I've talked about digital online acquiring for SME accounts, for cards, for unsecured.

Last quarter, for the first time, more than half of our mortgages came through direct sourcing without going through brokers, without going through developers, principally on account of our online activities in the mortgage space.
Similarly our (inaudible) [and waste] are improving across every category.
Not just through payments where we are up in the 90% range, but all of the other products that we do as well.
So we're seeing cost improvement there.
We have been able to simplify our business model and our [online structures] in some businesses, principally SME, where we re-thought our strategy in several markets and tightened it a bit.

The commodities business where we scaled down the business and the brokerage business where, as I alluded to before, we really unbundled the business activity and taken the retail part of it into wells and the institutional part of it more tightly coupled with capital markets.
So in all of these cases, we've been able to see efficiencies that flowed through.
And finally, in terms of our technology, as we in-source more and more of our technologies from an application standpoint into Hyderabad.
And [as we are limiting] cloud architecture, moving away from the large data, large mainframe construct to more micro services and commoditized hardware construct.
We are seeing the benefits of that come through quite nicely as well.

So we're quite confident that we should continue to see efficiency in the expense side because all of the programs that we've launched are already delivering us value, and we see that continue to happen as we go forward.
All right, in terms of portfolio, this is a slide I've been using so I just want to take you back to the slide to this $7 billion out of exposure in the support services ex HIBOR.
Of that, $1.6 billion is still to government-linked shipyard, mostly in Singapore, so we don't consider that at risk.
The residue in the portfolio is about $5.4 billion.
And we've, in the past, shown that there are 2 categories in that.
There are 5 large names, $2.4 billion.
That used to be $2.6 billion, it has come down only because we wrote off some in that category.
[Note that] Aviva business is about $2.4 billion.
And then on the other side, we have circa hundred-odd names where we are $3 billion in exposure overall.
Now the sector continues to stay challenged, and we're going to start with these oil struggles to get over $50.
And as long as oil is staying in the $45 to $50 range, 2 things are happening.
One, like I said, as I've said before, there is very little new development activity happening.
And so that part of the industry in the business, people are supporting building and exploration, that's been challenged for 2 years, and that's already factored in.
But the other thing that's happening even in producing (technical difficulty) and servicing, while the contracts are picking up somewhat, the oil and gas service players don't have any pricing power.
So they've been able to get short-term contracts and rollover contracts but they've not been able to price up.
And the prices that they're getting for the contracts right now, they're barely able to cover OpEx.
So it's really hard for them on a sustained basis to cover interest and principal.
So that continues to be the case.
And as long as oil prices stay in this range, I'm seeing it very hard for the sector to regain anything [real] pricing power.
So that's why it's been (inaudible).
I think the sector will still remain challenged because people have not been able to price up.
Oil majors, if you look at all of the announcements, they are factoring in long-term view that oil will stay at $50.
And therefore, they are recalibrating the cost to a $50 oil price.
As a consequence there, they [don't choose] to pay the suppliers any more than they paid in the last year or 2.
Therefore, pricing has really been [hard] for most contractors.
If we look at where we are on -- let's start on the right, on the $3 billion portfolio.
And as we have said that about 60% of that is weak, right?
And the thing, of that, about $800 million, $0.8 billion has already moved to nonperforming in which -- of which about $600 million actually moved this year in the first 6 months of this year.
Our total provisions against that portfolio, the nonperforming portfolio, are in the $300 million and some million range against that.
I think of the residual weak portfolio, which is quite about $1 billion, which is still weak, I think a large part of that will move to nonperforming in the rest of this year and in next year.
So I expect to see NPA formation of roughly the same level of the first half as we go into the second half.
And therefore, the SPs for the second half in relation to the nonperforming, new nonperforming, will be about the same as the first half.
So we took about $300 million in the first half, and we likely will take about $300 million in the second half, which relates to the new nonperforming loans in this category.
Now that's consistent with what we said.
If you look at what I've written as our previous assessment is intact on that standpoint.
So we are seeing no new cases getting into the watch list.
So we're not seeing new weak names.
It's just that the names that appears here identified as weak are moving into NPA as we projected they would and are likely to continue to do that the rest of this year and into next year.
The risk in this category actually comes not from incremental NPAs but comes from collateral values and whether we need to take more provisions on the ships, which are currently in nonperforming.
That is possible.
And that is possible because collateral values are continuing to come down.
Our latest set of collateral values are almost 40%, 50% lower than this time last year.
And collateral values are reflecting the fact that, what I said earlier, there is no pricing power in the sector and, therefore, collateral values continues to edge down in the sector.
If collateral values continue to creep further lower, and I said before, we want to do ships which are bespoke, so we're going to figure out how we can -- what price we give to them.
It is possible that we might have to take more provisions against that loss so existing NPAs.
In the normal course, I'd expect that to be normal, say, another $300 million.
And a lot of that could happen next year as opposed to this year.
But it depends on how our negotiations go and when we actually sail the ships.
So some of that could still go into this year as well, if that's what happens.
Finally, the names on the left.
2 of those names are in nonperforming.
After the write-offs, the NPL related to that, it's about $600 million.
The other 3 names in that, in the past we've said they're relatively robust in terms of the contract they have and the awards that they have on hand.
But at least a couple of those names have some large liquidity events coming due in the next 12 to 18 months, a large bond maturity.
And over the next 6 to 12 months, we have to work with these names to reprofile, restructure, so that they can handle this liquidity event.
And when we go through the process, there's always some degree of risk that you might have even during shock coming from one of those things.
As you go to through the reprofiling, restructuring process.
So that's the -- if we were to put it together, we really made guidance that are total SPs for this year should be roughly the same as last year ex HIBOR.
And in the normal cost, that's what we'd expect.
However, if -- depending on collateral values and our ability to dispose of some assets in the back-end of the year, that might creep up.
There might be more.
And then obviously, depending on if we wind up unfortunately in some event over the next year and 1.5 years, and we'd have to look at that separately.
Ex that, my own assessment is that SPs, assuming that the collateral issue happens next year and not this year, you should see about $300 million of SPs next year from new NPA formation.
You might see, like I said, another $300 million from lower collateral in the worst case, which should mean that next year SPs will be pretty similar to this year's SPs BAU basis.
So on our outlook.
Our loan pipeline, like we said, is healthy.
Third quarter has continued to be very robust.
We saw 3% loan growth in the first half of the year.
We think we should be able to get 3% at least in the second half of the year.
So we'll be at the high end of the mid-single digit guidance we gave earlier.
Income for the second half, we should see at least mid-single-digit growth, partly because the basic comparison on margins will be better.
Partly because we do have a more positive outlook on the flow-through for both SOR and HIBOR in the second half of the year, and this is fundamentally driven by our view on currencies.
It's in -- the Sing dollar which hit $1.36 and has gone back.
As the Sing dollar starts weakening, if it weakens, you'll see a stronger U.S. dollar over the next few months.
That should allow a better pass-through of rates into SOR over the next several months.
And like I said, in July, SOR and SIBOR were already up almost 10 to 20 basis points compared to the second quarter.
So we should see some impact of that flow through into our NIM.
Similarly, on the Hong Kong dollar side, the Hong Kong dollar is weak ironically.
As it starts weakening, it's already at $7.82.
As it starts heading to the $7.85 top of the band, and you should start seeing some reversal in the rates in HIBOR, and you've begun to see that.
In the last few weeks, HIBOR has also moved up by 7, 8 basis points in the 1 month.
Projection is that you'll start seeing that back up again.
And therefore, based on that, we think our NIM should be up by a couple basis points as we go forward from here.
On top of that, we should get another hike.
Even if the hike is postponed for December, we might see a couple of these impacts from the hike as well.

So net-net, our own sense is that we should be able to see a few -- 2, 3 basis points lift in margins in the second half of the year, which should give us a full year average of 1.75, 1.76, somewhere in that range hopefully.
Cost to income ratio, we've guided before, I think we should be able to retain our cost efficiency, keep them in the 43% range.
And SPs, I just talked to you about that we could be higher than what we previously guided depending on what comes in with the collateral value as we go forward.
All right.
So I'll stop.
We're happy to take questions.
Are there any questions?
If you ask your questions, just one request again, to make use of mics in front of you.
We have some roving mics, so that the ones who are watching via webcast can hear the question.
Is there a first question?
This is [Julia Pond] from Bloomberg.
Quite a lot going on.
Could you talk a bit about NIM in the first -- in the second quarter?
I mean, I want to understand a bit better about HIBOR impact on the NIM.
Certainly, we find that last year that our liability profile in Hong Kong has moved.
It used to be about 40% CASA, today it's about 60% CASA.
So since our liabilities at CASA means the rates are fairly steady and low, our loan book is priced -- 75% of our loan book is price off HIBOR, of which the vast majority is priced off 1-month HIBOR.
So if 1-month HIBOR goes up and our cost of funding based on CASA does not move, then our margin goes up.
If 1-month HIBOR comes down, then our margin comes down.
1-month HIBOR came down very sharply in the last quarter.
And it came down very sharply because of the huge increase in Hong Kong dollar liquidity.
Now why is the increase in Hong Kong dollar liquidity is a little uncertain.
My own speculation is part of that reflects reconversions from CNH back to Hong Kong dollar.
If you look at the CNH (technical difficulty) at its peak, it's peaked at about $1 trillion.
It's now come down to about $400 billion.
So over the last several months, there's been a reconversion of almost half of $1 trillion from CNH back to Hong Kong dollars.
I think that's propelling a lot of Hong Kong dollar liquidity.
The second is people are selling dollars for Hong Kong dollars in the past.
People have been seeing a strengthening of the Hong Kong dollar means something.
So there's just a lot of Hong Kong dollar liquidity which has [come in largely lumping up].
And as a consequence, the HIBOR has been hedging lower.
But the way, the Central Bank does its monetary policy and the currency band, as the Hong Kong dollar depreciates and gets closer to 7.85, then [GME] will come in and intervene.
It's now at 7.82.
And on this 7.82, you're beginning to see some people reversing their positions.
They're not sure whether it's a Central Bank intervention or it's the market reversing its position.
And therefore, HIBOR begins to creep up again.
Now so that basically explains roughly almost a 2 basis point reduction in our NIM because of that HIBOR impact.
And also on the new NPA formation, what's your guidance for the rest of the year?
Do you expect lumpy?
As I've said, if you look at our -- we already said of our $3 billion portfolio like (inaudible), so roughly 60%, or $1.8 billion, is weak.
Out of that $800 million is already in NPA.
So call it as another $1 billion of weak names in that log.
Of that, I expect half of that to move to NPA this year.
Another $500 million.
Another $500 million.
I think the point of what I just said, we are not seeing asset quality pressure anywhere of significance outside (inaudible) sectors.
We're not seeing it in consumer including Singapore outside.
There's some episodic cases much in the news as well, but they're -- so they don't move the needle that much around.
And so we're not seeing too much pressure anywhere.
The (inaudible) sector continues be challenged.
And because we already identified the sources of weakness, we know where it is, it's just a question of how much continues to move to nonperforming and at what stage.
That's where I gave some details on earlier.
[Richard Hart], [managing banker].
You mentioned digitalization and productivity have a 1% impact, and there's been a lot done.
Do you see a continuation of reduction in expenses due to digitalization that's going to be significant?
And if so, what kinds of thing is that going to come from?
Well, I pointed out the 4 areas on my slide, we can go back to that slide.
I just wanted to ask what -- how has digitalization affected cost from the side of banking unit in particular and what impact has it had on the cost to income ratio.
Also secondly, what was some of the challenges during the year in that integration for high net worth clients in particular, and what kind of AUM is coming over?
So our total cost to income ratio on the high net worth thing, I'm just trying to remember that number to 59.
Is it down from...
We don't normally disclose -- (inaudible) off the record.
All right.
So it's been coming down regularly.
I once said it was 58% or 59%, which is a record because the industry average is in the 70s.
So we have been very, very efficient in our wealth management business, on the top end.
As we have been very successful with iWealth, we continue to get even better cost.
iWealth has been fantastic thing for us, it's extremely well regarded.
More and more customers are happy to bid online, you can bid 24/7, you can do equity, you can manage your portfolio.
The feedback on that is very strong.
And more and more, even our wealthy customers are bringing through self-service on the back of iWealth.
And that really continues therefore to drive an improvement in our cost to income ratio at the top end of wealth.
Internal integration as I've told you we only integrated China so far.
And that's not a consequential business.
So the big pieces are going to be Singapore tomorrow and Hong Kong in a couple of months.

So the big challenge with the wealth integration is always post integration, which is around KYC and customer due diligence because our privacy laws, we really don't know what customers you're going to inherit till you actually get them on your book.
And your due diligence should take a look in the policy they have, what kinds of (inaudible) they have.
So that you have a high degree confidence that the customer policies are good.
So hopefully, they don't have bad lemons.
But once the customer actually comes onboard, you have to repeat for all the customers.
And then you got to go customer by customer and make sure you're comfortable with that customer or not.
So that is typically the biggest challenge with wealth integration, and that is still ahead of us.
So that will happen as integration takes place.
Of the total AUMs invest of about $20 billion that we get from this thing, when -- I haven't look at this, but when we did the original DD, about 1/3 of that was from the high wealth category.
Jamie?
Jamie from the Business Times, two questions.
One on restructuring in the oil and gas sector.
Regarding the vessels, is there a way in which to repurpose these vessels?
Talk about how can that be done.
How optimistic are you about that?
And the second area, just a follow-up on Wealth Management, do you therefore see the costs going up?
I mean, people have also talked about how Wealth Management is inherently a very expensive business, especially for the high end, you still need expensive relationship managers.
I assume that you're still building out the business.
So how much more investments do you see in the space?
So the first, it is possible to repurpose, but that's one of the -- my realizations over the last 12, 18 months, it's not that easy.
And where people have repurposed their ship, they've been able to.
It takes some CapEx.
So we got to first put some money into the ship to repurpose it, and then you're going to look at the rates you're able to get for the repurpose itself.
And in turns out that because of the overall climate, even the repurposed ships don't get very high rate.
So even there, there is challenge, even after repurposing.
So you put some money, repurpose the ship, you do -- you put it to work.
So again, you can put it to work, you can get cash flows, but you don't get the same kind of rates that you used to see years ago.
On the Wealth Management business, I guess, there are 2 things because we invest in Wealth Management and we continue investing.
The question is, do we make more money than we spend?
And we make more money than we spend, which is why our cost to income ratio keeps improving.
If you go back to the whole notion of why are we more cost efficient in wealth than anybody else.
And we've said that before, we have continued the wealth platform.
We uniquely run private banks, private clients, and mass affluent (inaudible) off the common platform.
And because of that, we get tremendous synergies and economies of scale which none of our competitors do.
We run a common backbone whether it's technology, compliance, legal, product selection, et cetera.
We just have differences at the front end of the model.
Second, our digitization of the wealth thing has proven to be very beneficial.
So it allows us to do a lot more to the business channel.
And finally, one of the positive outcomes of the wealth continuum is, in addition to getting customer mobility, we also get stock mobility.
So many of our private bankers, they promote from the private clients.
And many of private client bankers, they promote from mass affluent.
And all the way down from our branches.
And in fact, I was just showing a case of someone who had started as a DBS teller and has worked all the way up into being a private banker.
Now when you promote and move your people internally, you don't see the very high cost you do when you try to hire from the market.
So overall, we continue to invest, but our efficiency ratios continue to improve.
(inaudible)
Just on the risk weighted asset, just on the CAR, your fully loaded Tier 1.
What was the nature of the risk weighted assets?
Was it -- is that what sell for the cost to go -- for the CAR which is higher than the other 2 banks?
We're you talking about ratio or just the risk-weighted assets?
For the CAR ratio, 14.2% last quarter to 14.0%, actually due to the payout of the dividend during the quarter.
The question is why is your capital ratio higher than the other banks?
So much higher than the other bank.
I think we have been conservative in accretion of capital.
The earnings growth has been good, and we have also had a consistent scrip dividend policy.
(inaudible) And the second question on the  exposure to or likely impact on IFRS 9 on your financials, P&L, balance sheet and capital.

So we are still working through the numbers, and we should be able to have a fuller assessment in the next quarter because the MAS guidance on the IFRS 9, they have done a consultation paper, but they have not finalized the approach.
So the final numbers will depend very much on whether MAS goes for the approach 1 or the approach 2 on their consultation paper.
Well, approach 1 is kind of aligned to the IFRS 9 that is published globally, but the minimum 1% provision that's required is a movement to reserve.
Approach 2 is more similar to what we have today.
You need to meet the 1% minimum requirement is passed through the P&L but you have the full IFRS 9 disclosure as a disclosure note.
So these are the 2 approaches that's been consulted with the industry.

As far as we understand, the banks have a preference to actually continue with the current approach which is more conservative, to actually take the 1% requirement through the P&L with full disclosure of the IFRS 9 numbers as a disclosure.
[Mariko].
[Mariko] from Nikkei.
I have 2 questions.
One is about the cost.
You have 1% expense, a little lower expenses this quarter.
And I believe technology has played a role.
But how is the outlook for the savings because of the digitization?
How long is it going to continue?
And is it going to be bigger from now or once it's done, it's done?
Another is about Digibank.
You had India and you were planning to have in Malaysia.
Can you give us an update?
Highly syndicated.
I think, this is a continuous journey, and I think there's significant opportunities to take cost out of the system through all of the measures we identified.

The fact that I think than we can bring our cost to income ratio down to 40% over the next 3 or 4 years means that we should be able to continue to get cost efficiency every year over the next few years to get it.
So I think it's an ongoing journey.
It's a good segue.
Now know that if you were to do a complete digital bank, Digibank kind of thing, you can run a cost to income ratio in the low 30s.
I think that's possible to do based on essentially no branch infrastructure at the front end, straight-through processing regime, and using AI and chat box at the back end.
So even though you wind up with customer acquisition cost, your actual processing and servicing cost is very, very low.
That's what we've been able to see with Digibank in India.
We're now at about 1.3 million customers, actually 1.4 million in July customers.
Of that, about 300,000 are full savings account customers.
We are processing that with about 60-odd people.
In the normal course, we would need like 400, 500 people to do that scale.
We need 60 people.
By year-end, we think we'll be down to half, so 30 people.
If you can design for something like that, the costs can be very low.
Now the reality is, you can't get to that level where you have a legacy base.

So it will be very hard to get to a low 30 cost to income ratio for us in Singapore, for example, because we got branches, customers, heartland and all bunch of things, but that's a go-to that over -- we have to think over 10 years what could banks get to, I think that is possible.
And Digibank in India we are very encouraged.
Customer acquisition has continued at over 100,000 customers every month.
We get them both directly as well as through channel partners.
So the China partnership approach is kicking in nicely.
Various acquisitions kicking in nicely.
Balance buildup is very consistent and good.
Like every good fintech, we're losing money.
And we expect to continue to invest and lose money for 3 or 4 years.
But if you look at the comparison, if we try to do the same buildup in an old-fashioned branch model, you need like 15, 20 years to pay back.
In a digital model, you can get that scale and presence and still look to getting a breakeven in 3, 4 years.
I'm afraid that's really all the time we have today.
So thank you all for coming.
We should go and take your questions offline, sorry.
Thank you, everyone, for coming.
See you next quarter.
Thank you, everybody.
But I've said that over the next few years, we hope to bring be able to bring our cost to income ratio down to 40% from what is now 43%.
We peaked at 45.5%, we're down to 43%, we're headed in the right direction.
And if you build out a trajectory, we think we can get to 40% over the next few years.
And it comes from all of these things.
We think there are dues in each of the 4 categories that are laid out.
So in terms of the distribution costs, so far, we haven't had to reduce branches.
But over time, over the next 3, 5 years, yes, we should be able to rationalize the branch footprint itself.
So far, if you look at Netherlands, the branches are down to 25% of what they were 5 years ago.
If you look at Scandinavia, branches are down to 30% to 40% of what they used to be.
Our own footfall in our branches is coming down.
And it's coming down because we rapidly continue to move people onto different channels.
So as more and more people are using ibanking, [fill up], (inaudible), they don't come to the branch for doing branch activity.
We've seen a reduction of almost 3% to 4% in footfall in the branches.
We're equally being able to rationalize our ATMs, in fact, that, we're already doing partly because we've been able to create a new generation of ATMs.
And earlier, we had 2 sets of machine.
Machines in which you put in cash and machines for which you could take out cash.
Today, we can rationalize, and you can put in cash and take out cash from the same machine.
That is quite a dramatic impact because not only can we reduce the number of machines, but it saves the number of cash trips we need to make.

So earlier, we have a bunch of people who are going to withdraw cash from 1 set of machine and bring it back and count it and then another bunch of people going to load cash into the other set of machines.
Now because the cash goes into the machine, it just cuts down the number of trips.
Our total cost of cash handling in Singapore is almost $100 million, $80 million to $100 million.
So as you rationalize both the machine and the cash recycling process, you see visible saves in that as an example.
The second I talked about is end-to-end process digitization.
We're moving a lot more of our business to online inquiry.
That's true in credit cards and unsecured, which are easier, but now we are doing that in bank insurance and mortgages, we're doing that in SME origination, we're doing that in SME loans.
And as you acquire online, your cost to acquisition goes down.
So that will continue to be the case.
There's a lot of opportunity to continue to shift to online acquisition.
We're also moving a lot of our business straight-through because we're killing paper.
So the minute you kill paper, you just don't need to do the manual entries and the paper handling.
The transaction goes straight through from the customer all the way to our back-end system, so you just eliminate work.
So we're doing that in every category.
And then the fourth category, which is the technology infrastructure.
Moving from all legacy technology architecture to cloud native architecture has massive impact on expenses both on your hardware, on your data center infrastructures, on the software.
And on top of that because in sourcing, we're also reducing our sourcing costs from vendors and providers as well.
So all of these are very positive.
Just wondering the online acquisition supply industry.
That's right.
I think (inaudible) had a question, and then after that Jamie.
